question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('f00837b6-6af2-4d4e-9297-57fe1f50d71a'), title='Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen

Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE

not_P: 0.27

0.73

RECEIVED

In this scenario, we are assessing various probabilities related to Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event and his public statements regarding Bitcoin before this event. 

1. **P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This probability will depend on factors such as his past attendance at similar events, current public engagements, and any statements he has made regarding his participation. I estimate this probability to be moderately high, reflecting a reasonable chance that he may not show up given the unpredictable nature of his schedule. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk showing up)**: This is the complement of P, and thus it should logically be 1 - P. If I estimate P at 0.6, then not_P would be 0.4. 

3. **para_P (Elon Musk's absence)**: This is essentially the same as P, so I would expect it to have the same value. 

4. **Q (Elon Musk making a public statement about Bitcoin)**: This depends on his historical behavior regarding Bitcoin and his engagement with the cryptocurrency community. Given his active involvement in Bitcoin discussions, I estimate this probability to be relatively high. 

5. **P_and_Q (Both not showing up and making a statement)**: This probability will be lower than either P or Q alone, as both events occurring together is less likely than either occurring independently. I would estimate this to be a product of the individual probabilities, adjusted for any correlation between the events.

6. **P_or_Q (At least one of the events occurring)**: This probability will be higher than either P or Q alone, as it accounts for the possibility of either event happening. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Making a statement and showing up)**: This is a scenario that is likely to be low, as it would mean he is active in the Bitcoin space while also attending the event, which could be mutually exclusive depending on the timing of his statement. 

8. **Q_given_P (Making a statement given he does not show up)**: This conditional probability would likely be higher than the unconditional Q, as he might make a statement to address his absence or engage with the community in other ways.

The relationships between these probabilities are crucial, especially regarding their independence. P and not_P are complementary, while Q and P may not be directly related but could influence each other based on Musk's engagement with Bitcoin. 

Overall, I will need to ensure that my estimates respect the consistency rules provided.

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.42,
P_or_Q: 0.88,
Q_and_not_P: 0.28,
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.60 = 1 - 0.40 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.88 + 0.42 - 0.70 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.42 <= min(0.60, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.70) <= 0.88 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.70) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.88 - 0.28 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.42 / 0.75 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE

neg, andor, or, cond consistency checks failed!

Q: 0.65,

P_or_Q: 0.85,
Q_and_not_P: 0.26,
Q_given_P: 0.70

0.6

The questions presented revolve around Elon Musk's potential actions and statements regarding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference. Here's a breakdown of the reasoning for each probability estimate:

1. **P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Elon Musk's history of public appearances and his engagement with the cryptocurrency community, I estimate a moderate probability that he will not attend. This estimate is influenced by the nature of the event and Musk's recent behavior regarding public engagements.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain probability, not_P will be 1 minus that probability. Thus, if P is estimated at 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will be absent from the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially the same as P, so I would expect para_P to have the same probability as P.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public statement about Bitcoin before the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Musk's active engagement with Bitcoin in the past, I would estimate a higher probability that he will make a public statement before the conference.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: To estimate this, I would consider the probabilities of P and Q occurring together. Since these events may not be entirely independent, I would adjust this estimate accordingly.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is a broader estimate that considers the likelihood of either event happening. The probability would be higher than either P or Q alone.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q and not_P occur?)**: This is a combination of Q happening and Musk not showing up. I would estimate this based on the relationship between Q and not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability will depend on how likely Q is if P is true. If Musk does not show up, he may still make a statement about Bitcoin, affecting this estimate.

In summary, these probabilities are interconnected, and changes to one will necessitate adjustments to others to maintain consistency according to the established rules. I will ensure that all estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided.

and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.45 <= min(0.65, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.70) <= 0.80 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.70) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.80 - 0.25 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.45 / 0.50 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE
